Determine if we're running in a standard browser environment

This allows axios to run in a web worker, and react-native.
Both environments support XMLHttpRequest, but not fully standard globals.

web workers:
typeof window -> undefined
typeof document -> undefined

react-native:
navigator.product -> 'ReactNative'
nativescript
navigator.product -> 'NativeScript' or 'NS'

Once you've invoked the script, it will parse the HTML body of the response messages and print the text of each HTML comment as it finds them. You can then use the print statements to modify the code and test the script without affecting the actual functionality of the proxy. Note, however, that we've only shown you how to add comments to the script; actually writing a script and using it as a proxied script is more complex.
Writing scripts is complex because they often need to access external resources, create proxy-specific objects, interact with other Java code in the Squid proxy, and more. There are a number of tools and resources available that can help you accomplish this.
The main tools you will need are:
* The Squid source code, for which the most recent version is the Squid site (http://www.squid-cache.org/)

doc.original_string:
function Table(props) {
  const {
    attached,
    basic,
    celled,
    children,
    className,
    collapsing,
    color,
    columns,
    compact,
    definition,
    fixed,
    footerRow,
    headerRow,
    headerRows,
    inverted,
    padded,
    renderBodyRow,
    selectable,
    singleLine,
    size,
    sortable,
    stackable,
    striped,
    structured,
    tableData,
    textAlign,
    unstackable,
    verticalAlign,
  } = props

  const classes = cx(
    'ui',
    color,
    size,
    useKeyOnly(celled, 'celled'),
    useKeyOnly(collapsing, 'collapsing'),
    useKeyOnly(definition, 'definition'),
    useKeyOnly(fixed, 'fixed'),
    useKeyOnly(inverted, 'inverted'),
    useKeyOnly(selectable, 'selectable'),
    useKeyOnly(singleLine, 'single line'),
    useKeyOnly(sortable, 'sortable'),
    useKeyOnly(stackable, 'stackable'),
    useKeyOnly(striped, 'striped'),
    useKeyOnly(structured, 'structured'),
    useKeyOnly(unstackable, 'unstackable'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(attached, 'attached'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(basic, 'basic'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(compact, 'compact'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(padded, 'padded'),
    useTextAlignProp(textAlign),
    useVerticalAlignProp(verticalAlign),
    useWidthProp(columns, 'column'),
    'table',
    className,
  )
  const rest = getUnhandledProps(Table, props)
  const ElementType = getElementType(Table, props)

  if (!childrenUtils.isNil(children)) {
    return (
      <ElementType {...rest} className={classes}>
        {children}
      </ElementType>
    )
  }

  const hasHeaderRows = headerRow || headerRows
  const headerShorthandOptions = { defaultProps: { cellAs: 'th' } }
  const headerElement = hasHeaderRows && (
    <TableHeader>
      {TableRow.create(headerRow, headerShorthandOptions)}
      {_.map(headerRows, (data) => TableRow.create(data, headerShorthandOptions))}
    </TableHeader>
  )

  return (
    <ElementType {...rest} className={classes}>
      {headerElement}
      <TableBody>
        {renderBodyRow &&
          _.map(tableData, (data, index) => TableRow.create(renderBodyRow(data, index)))}
      </TableBody>
      {footerRow && <TableFooter>{TableRow.create(footerRow)}</TableFooter>}
    </ElementType>
  )
}

function Grid(props) {
  const {
    celled,
    centered,
    children,
    className,
    columns,
    container,
    divided,
    doubling,
    inverted,
    padded,
    relaxed,
    reversed,
    stackable,
    stretched,
    textAlign,
    verticalAlign,
  } = props

  const classes = cx(
    'ui',
    useKeyOnly(centered, 'centered'),
    useKeyOnly(container, 'container'),
    useKeyOnly(doubling, 'doubling'),
    useKeyOnly(inverted, 'inverted'),
    useKeyOnly(stackable, 'stackable'),
    useKeyOnly(stretched, 'stretched'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(celled, 'celled'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(divided, 'divided'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(padded, 'padded'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(relaxed, 'relaxed'),
    useMultipleProp(reversed, 'reversed'),
    useTextAlignProp(textAlign),
    useVerticalAlignProp(verticalAlign),
    useWidthProp(columns, 'column', true),
    'grid',
    className,
  )
  const rest = getUnhandledProps(Grid, props)
  const ElementType = getElementType(Grid, props)

  return (
    <ElementType {...rest} className={classes}>
      {children}
    </ElementType>
  )
}

doc.original_string:
function GridColumn(props) {
  const {
    children,
    className,
    computer,
    color,
    floated,
    largeScreen,
    mobile,
    only,
    stretched,
    tablet,
    textAlign,
    verticalAlign,
    widescreen,
    width,
  } = props

  const classes = cx(
    color,
    useKeyOnly(stretched, 'stretched'),
    useMultipleProp(only, 'only'),
    useTextAlignProp(textAlign),
    useValueAndKey(floated, 'floated'),
    useVerticalAlignProp(verticalAlign),
    useWidthProp(computer, 'wide computer'),
    useWidthProp(largeScreen, 'wide large screen'),
    useWidthProp(mobile, 'wide mobile'),
    useWidthProp(tablet, 'wide tablet'),
    useWidthProp(widescreen, 'wide widescreen'),
    useWidthProp(width, 'wide'),
    'column',
    className,
  )
  const rest = getUnhandledProps(GridColumn, props)
  const ElementType = getElementType(GridColumn, props)

  return (
    <ElementType {...rest} className={classes}>
      {children}
    </ElementType>
  )
}

function Segment(props) {
  const {
    attached,
    basic,
    children,
    circular,
    className,
    clearing,
    color,
    compact,
    content,
    disabled,
    floated,
    inverted,
    loading,
    placeholder,
    padded,
    piled,
    raised,
    secondary,
    size,
    stacked,
    tertiary,
    textAlign,
    vertical,
  } = props

  const classes = cx(
    'ui',
    color,
    size,
    useKeyOnly(basic, 'basic'),
    useKeyOnly(circular, 'circular'),
    useKeyOnly(clearing, 'clearing'),
    useKeyOnly(compact, 'compact'),
    useKeyOnly(disabled, 'disabled'),
    useKeyOnly(inverted, 'inverted'),
    useKeyOnly(loading, 'loading'),
    useKeyOnly(placeholder, 'placeholder'),
    useKeyOnly(piled, 'piled'),
    useKeyOnly(raised, 'raised'),
    useKeyOnly(secondary, 'secondary'),
    useKeyOnly(stacked, 'stacked'),
    useKeyOnly(tertiary, 'tertiary'),
    useKeyOnly(vertical, 'vertical'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(attached, 'attached'),
    useKeyOrValueAndKey(padded, 'padded'),
    useTextAlignProp(textAlign),
    useValueAndKey(floated, 'floated'),
    'segment',
    className,
  )
  const rest = getUnhandledProps(Segment, props)
  const ElementType = getElementType(Segment, props)

  return (
    <ElementType {...rest} className={classes}>
      {childrenUtils.isNil(children) ? content : children}
    </ElementType>
  )
}

# Summary Card
FeedSummary is one of the three common feed card components. It’s designed to display a summary of a feed item.
There are three props:
- children: You can provide any child components to display within the card.
- className: You can apply custom CSS classes to the root element.
- content: This is an important prop. It allows you to pass any content that will be rendered within the card. It can be text, a photo, an icon, a badge, or even more complex components.
- date: You can use this prop to display a date. It takes the same props as FeedDate to style and format the date.
- user: This prop allows you to display a user on the card. Pass an object with the information you want to display, like { name: 'John Doe' }.
### FeedHeader Component
The FeedHeader component is another common feed card component. It’s used when you want to draw attention to some specific content. It’s great for emphasizing the main title of an item, offering a different look to a FeedSummary component.
There are two props:
- children: You can provide any child components to display

The `||` operator is used to provide a fallback value if the property does not exist. This is an example of a technique called "fall-back chaining", which is a common pattern in JavaScript.

doc.docstring: Rough heuristic used to find the package name for a given file. Idea is to move upwards looking for directories that have a `package.json` file. Once we find one, we report back the name from that file.

target: Rough heuristic used to find the package name for a given file . Idea is to move upwards looking for directories that have a package . json file . Once we find one we report back the name from that file .
arguments: async function findPackageFor ( filepath ) { let directory = filepath ; while ( directory !== '/' ) { const directoryToSearch = path . dirname ( directory ) ; const files = await fs . readdir ( directoryToSearch ) ; if ( files . indexOf ( 'package.json' ) !== - 1 ) { const packageJson = await fs . readJson ( path . join ( directoryToSearch , 'package.json' ) ) ; return packageJson . name ; } directory = path . resolve ( directory , '..' ) ; } throw new Error ( ` ${ filepath } ` ) ; }
resps:
This function gets a file path, goes through the directory structure from the top of the project down, looking for the first package.json file that it finds. The moment it finds one, it returns the name of the package defined in that package.json.

First, get the current directory where the file lives. Initialize the directory loop counter to this directory.

Now, start looping over the directories. In each directory, attempt to read through all the files to see if you see 'package.json'. You can stop exploring right away if you find one, because we're only interested in the first package that defines something.

If you find 'package.json', then read it and return the name of the package contained inside. This will be what we use to identify our library when making requests to the GitHub API.

While still looping over directories, if 'package.json' isn't found, move to its parent and start again.

This continues until the loop goes through the whole directory tree, from the top of our project down, and we hit the root, and there is still no 'package.json', in which case it throws an error

This implementation includes:

1. `list` array which represents the current class list of the SVG element.
2. `uniqueList` object which maps each unique class to its presence.
3. `index` which is the index of the specified class in `uniqueList`.
4. `found` boolean which is `true` if the specified class is present in `uniqueList`, `false` otherwise.
5. `add` boolean which is `true` if the specified class should be added (or removed), `false` otherwise.

The function then checks if `found` and `add` are inverted. If so:

* If `add` is `true`, add the specified class to the `uniqueList`.
* If `add` is `false`, remove the specified class from the `uniqueList`.
* Update the `class` attribute of the SVG element with the updated `uniqueList`.

This implementation uses modern JavaScript features such as arrow functions and `Object.assign()` to make the code concise and readable. It also follows best practices by using descriptive variable names and handling the case where the specified class is already present in the class list. ```c
